subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code
msgSnippet: With more realistic examples, it s nicer. When you use the try/catch form you can move some of your action code above the try. The problem with the annotation
messageBody:
With more realistic examples, it's nicer. When you use the try/catch
form you can move some of your action code above the try. The problem
with the annotation solution is that it doesn't point out the call that
is supposed to throw the exception: it could be any call in the test method.

It would be nice if there was an elegant solution in Java. If the
language had closures you could so something like this:

public void testSomething() {
space.resume();
assertException(InvalidState.class, { space.act(); });
}


Michael Feathers
michaelfeathers.typepad.com
www.objectmentor.com
